title: Galaxy Note 2 Clip for Bose 20i QC Headphones

description.text:
Made at the request of a user, relates to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:387492 that I made a few weeks ago.
Personally, i do not own a Galaxy Note 2, nor have i yet printed this particular file so I'm not 100% sure it fits. I made a model of the phone from some online blueprints, then fit the clip to the model. Should fit just fine directly to the phone. Maybe even with a case on as even with 100% infill; my previous design remained fairly flexible.
Take care which .stl you download, there is one with a little clip for guiding the wire and one without. Up to you which you choose...
If you just want one big clip rather than two little ones -- scale along Z axis ;)
You're welcome to be the Guinea Pig and report back on the fitment for other users ;)

title: Ratchet and Pawl Mechanism
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A ratchet mechanism: the sawtooth gear rotates inside the outer wheel in only one direction due to the integrated spring-loaded pawl which blocks backward rotation but moves out of the way for forward rotation. Warning: This is an experimental, work in progress, proof of concept, and part of a larger unfinished project. If you just stumbled upon this, you may want to come back when the project is further along -- it's only here so people can play around with the mechanism. Reddit discussion about this item:
http://www.reddit.com/r/3Dprinting/comments/2bp6np/functional_ratchet_mechanism_3d_printed_in_abs/

The Outer_Wheel_with_Integrated_Pawl is not finalized and in need of a better support solution, so it needs some cleanup after printing because the roof falls in a little bit. (Adding generic support will likely destroy the spring mechanism by placing support on top of the spring.)
It should be printed at 0.1mm layer height and scale should not be adjusted. It is scaled so that the spring mechanism is exactly 1-layer wide for maximum flexibility and in a continuous curve for minimum breakability.

This is a knockoff lasercutter version of: http://evilmadscience.com/partsmenu/68-bender Windell H. Oskay from Evil Mad Science and Zach 'Hoeken' Smith helped work out the laser cutter design on the thingiverse mailing list. This is just a first try. I cut one in 3/16" plywood and it's usable, but not ideal. It's clearly going to break soon. The biggest problem is the thinness of some of the walls. In the commercial version there's a recessed channel, rather than a cut out channel as in this design. That gives the tool more strength.
Cut it out on a laser! Cut numbers and index lines first, then channel and hanging hole, then outline. Colored coded for your convenience.

title: Vacuum pick and place head for 3-axis machine v0.0

description.text: This is a vacuum pick-and-place head design for automated electronic assembly. It features a stepper-driven rotary head with Luer-Lock port for interchangeable needles, and a feature for attachment of an \"eyeball\" style Webcam for optical placement (you can modify to support your own favorite camera). Vacuum is provided to the head via flex (fishpump) tubing.

The .cb files can be opened with the freeware version of CamBam, available from http://www.cambam.co.uk/ First, make any desired modifications to the plates, such as changing the camera mount for a specific camera, and adding a mounting mechanism for your 3-axis machine (e.g. angle brackets, or a dovetail, etc.). Machine the top and bottom plate. The order of assembly is not critical, but it\'s probably best to do a test-fit before gluing anything down. Press-fit the ball bearing into the pocket on the top side of the bottom plate. The sleeve bearing screws onto the corresponding hole in the top plate using #4-40 bolts, and can be placed on either the top or bottom. The stepper motor mounts to the bottom side of the bottom plate using #4-40 bolts. The smaller of the two pulleys slides onto the motor shaft. Next assemble the structure by bolting the standoffs onto the top of the bottom plate, #8-32 bolts entering from the bottom. Secure the top plate to these standoffs using 4 more #8-32s. If you will use a camera, mount it too. Finally, assemble the rotating frame by passing the length of 1/4\" steel tubing through the sleeve bearing, followed by the larger pulley and timing belt, then the ball bearing. Slip the barbed end of the Luer-lock adapter into the bottom end of the tubing (screw on a needle if you like) and test the \"fit\" with your machine setup and camera. Determine the desired height of the steel tubing/needle, and cut the tubing to the desired length. Making it permanent: Secure the large and small pulleys and Luer adapter with a bit of adhesive. These should not see any significant load, so a dab will do. Likewise, take the plastic right-angle hose barb and glue it into the top of the steel tube. For the Luer adapter and hose barb, be careful not to clog the air path with adhesive! Finally, loosen the bolts holding the motor, loop the timing belt onto the motor pulley (moving the motor as necessary), then move the motor out to take up any slack in the belt and re-tighten the motor bolts. OPTICAL USER TIP: To determine the needle depth - With the camera focus set such that the largest part you will ever populate can fit in-frame, find the resulting camera height (distance from part) and set the depth of the shaft so that the camera is â€œin focusâ€ maybe an inch or two above the placement position (that is, the position with the needle touching the board). This will allow the head to focus on parts without touching the needle down. This should cover 99.999% of all SMD assembly uses, but if you will be somehow using it to move very tall objects, set the focus height at least a bit higher than the tallest part you will place. SOURCING MOTORS: The timing pulleys and stepper motors only come in a handful of diameters (imperial for the pulleys and usually metric for the small motors), so a 3mm (.118â€³) motor onto a .125â€³ ID pulley was the closest I could come up with in a reasonable amount of effort. Any small, el-cheapo permanent magnet (â€œtin canâ€) stepper motor should work here, but sourcing it may be annoying. Off-the-shelf 3mm-shaft motors I found are Jamecoâ€™s ValuePro 42BY48H08, Anaheim Automationâ€™s TSM42 series, and Portescapâ€™s 42/44 series e.g. 42Ã—048 and 42S100. The surplus stepper at http://www.allelectronics.com/make-a-store/item/SMT-125/4-WIRE-STEPPER-MOTOR-W/GEARS/1.html is also worth a look, but youâ€™ll have to remove a pre-attached plastic(?) gearhead. Beware, many of these smaller motors are 7.5deg/step, so even with the gear reduction, you will probably want to use a microstepping driver such as Linistepper to ensure adequate rotational resolution. On mine, I took a 2mm motor I had lying around (http://www.allelectronics.com/make-a-store/item/SMT-108/STEPPER-MOTOR-6-WIRE/1.html) and glued a bit of steel tubing onto its shaft to make it ~3mm for use with the pulley. Final note: There have been slight improvements to the design files after building the one shown in the photo, so yours will not be 100% identical to the photo. Final final note: "You do not have permission to edit this supplier" when trying to add suppliers, part numbers/URLs, etc. for the discrete parts. Anyone know what's going on with this? For now, please read from the parts list on my blog at http://tim.cexx.org/?p=728

A small box for a single speaker with a hole for a volume control on the side.

Print, snap in a speaker connect a volume control and amplifier (many available for cheap on ebay) and go.
I originally made this to try to make corn-starch monsters -- you can see the residue in the pictures, but I think my simple 555 based square wave tone generator wont do the trick. I'll try it with a small amp and sine wave produced from my phone or computer.

This is a simple bracket to put my printed 'saber on the wall. I used one inch acrylic rod for the blade but it works with the Force FX 'sabers from Hasbro or Master Replicas as well. It has a section for an LED and two button cell batteries to help light up the piercing. Though this is a work in progress the bracket is still usable as you can see in the pictures. I am making a couple of decorative caps (coming shortly) to cover the top and sides, hence it is a functional work in progress.

Print off this bracket and my 'saber body from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38825
Get some one inch acrylic rod for the blade and sand it to help defuse the light better.
Wrap some electrical tape around the end till it fits snug in the 'saber handle about two inches in.
Put your chosen LED electronics in the bracket and 'saber and slide it together.
Use the bracket to mark out the spacing and use two screws to mount the bracket in desired location.
Some suggestions, use it as a towel rack, stair rails or banisters, in the hall entrance, in your man cave, etc.

comments.text: Pretty neat.  I  came across this while looking for something I could print instead of paying $24 for some of the ones I see online.  Only comment I would make, as someone who has some of the more expencive replicas, is you should really only mount them vertically.  I have one that is pretty much ruined from being hung horizontally for about 6 months with a permanent bow to it.  Don't make my mistakes!  And may the force be with you.

description.text: This box is designed to protect the table beneath your PCB from scratches, while giving you full access to the PCB top layer.

Measure your own PCB with caliphers. Adjust the model to your needs in OpenSCAD, if you have a heated build platform you may remove the holes. If not you should keep them, it will make your model easy to bend even if you get some curling. You will have to adjust the PCB size (all numbers are in mm), and remember to add some slack. The model does not add any to your parameters. The STL file and image shows the model used with a STK500 atmel programmer clone. TODO
Improve the model by making sure all the overhangs in the PCB slot are less than 45 degrees.

comments.text: Another pretty nice benefit: it protects your circuit from shorts from previously cut resistor leads, wires and other conductive stuff. Great work! I've been meaning to design something like this, thanks for sharing it!

description.text: It's a funnel. Dimensions 155,155,128 mm. Made in Blender. It's for pouring stuff from big mouthed containers, to small mouthed containers. funnel.scad is a program I wrote to generate funnels of the specified size and shape. I used the generator to make a funnel to feed my fish :).

It should be printed in PLA, because PLA is biodegradable and will not kill you, I'm not so sure about ABS, but if you aren't using it for food, then it doesn't matter. You may need to scale it down to fit it in your printer.
The Afinia refuses to print the Blender funnel. To generate the fish food funnel run:
funnel(1.8, 72, 53, 14, 32, 11, 100); To generate the salt funnel run:
funnel(1.8, 40, 20, 35, 15, 10, 80); Note that I imported, then exported it from Blender because OpenSCAD exports to text STLs, which are 3 times bigger than binary STLs. I printed all these funnels with no support.

Update: script is here: https://github.com/bluecoast/SolderSCAD I wrote a script to convert solder stencil gerbers to STL via OpenSCAD. It takes advantage of the similarity between OpenSCAD and photoplotting by first converting all defined apertures to OpenSCAD modules, then calling them individually whenever that aperture is flashed later in the file. It doesn't yet handle draws (only flashes) or aperture macros, but those don't seem to be used in solder paste layers.

I haven't tried printing the result yet -- it may be totally infeasible. So this is just an experiment at this point. If someone does print one, please upload a photo. A fine-pitch board would want a 4 or 5-mil stencil -- so .10 -.13mm overall height (a challenge for sure). I imagine both sides will need to be pretty smooth -- I don't know how to print that or whether it's even possible (maybe printing on glass then doing a post-cure heat with another piece on top?). I have printed some thin, nice single layers in past (by accident :P) that look like they'd work. Some directions to take this:
-importing the board outline (right now just adds 10cm to the min and max coords to form the actual stencil part)
-using that info to make a pocket for localizing the stencil
-it will be harder to implement draws... maybe as hulls of each consecutive pair of coordinates in sequence (that would work for lines anyway). Not needed for stencils regardless.
-I haven't even looked at what an aperture macro is. If they are just sets of lesser apertures, that would be fairly easy to handle
-everything is converted directly to 3D... might be faster to convert to a big 2D shape and extrude it (my script was under a second for the example STL; OpenSCAD however took 8 minutes to render it)

comments.text: I've developed a somewhat clumsy but doable technique for printing with conductive filament.  The transfer of the design from PCB CAD to OpenSCAD is comically crude at best, but you know what?  It works!  I use EAGLE CAD's print to file of custom sized PDF images to print the layers and the vias, then convert to PNG with a Mac utility (Preview), add registration marks to preserve alignment and height off of the bed, then I print using Zhop set large enough to skip over details from the insulating filament while the conductive filament is printed.  Or that's the plan, I have only printed one test board so far and it turned out very promising!  Please keep us posted if you decide to tackle a Gerber2STL converter or something like that!  And thanks for this work, it looks promising!

comments.text: You're right -- printing this may be totally infeasible. I am optimistic though --  Filament going down too wide can be compensated for by dilating the apertures (for instance). For 0805 or larger (all but four components on the STL I show) you can probably get away with something thicker (not that 10 mils is easy either). To an extent, you are trying to control volume of solder, not necessarily trying to cover the whole pad, so a grossly too-thick stencil might still work if the aperture area is decreased. I can certainly print a single 0.2 mm layer that I think would be good enough to work (not sure if I can get it off my bed intact though).
comments.author: qharley

comments.text: This sounds good.  You are right, it is the volume that counts.  I have failed prints on single layers (incorrect colour) that came of fine as a single layer intact.  I am watching this one...

This also should have less friction than ABS. So far it works well.

title: model joint for Ultimate Ascent Pyramid

description.text: This 1:8 scale model might help you think about how to climb the pyramid in FRC's 2013 event - Ultimate Ascent

Print 12 copies of this part - I had to open up the holes with a 3/16" drill bit for a good fit.
Cut 4 each of the following lengths of 3/16" dowel
13"
3.125"
6.25"
9.375" Assemble as shown in the finished model, which is based off the team drawings for the pyramid.

comments.text:
I would like to give a huge thank you to engunneer for sharing this! It's fantastic and easy to build! :)
My learnings:
The angled holes are so close to 3/16" that you can just ream them out easily by hand (slide the reamer in to the hole and twist with your fingers).
Mark the 13" dowels with a sharpie marker where you want the rungs to sit.
To assemble:
Start by gluing the top smallest square together (krazy glue works great for aluminum and plastic bonding). Make sure the square is flat.
Assemble the pyramid upside down: Place the small square upside down on the table (it should be stable now that you've glued it) and put the 13" legs into the angled holes on your small square. Put Krazy glue around the gap between the 13" leg and the plastic bracket. Gravity will pull the glue into the gap, so you don't need to take the leg out of the plastic to do this.
Slide a plastic bracket onto each 13" leg and put the connecting dowels in. Use Scotch tape to hold the plastic bracket to the rung, and make sure the tape is not touching the 13" leg. This will allow you to slide this middle-sized square up and down into position later.
Slide a plastic bracket onto each 13" leg again and put the long connecting dowels in. Use Scotch tape to hold the plastic bracket to the long connecting dowls, again making sure that the tape is not touching the 13" leg.
Now it should be safe to turn the pyramid right side up. Adjust the height of the two lower levels to your liking. I would suggest using a tape measure and a level so you don't get a funny gap like I did.
Once everything is adjusted, take the Scotch tape off of one angle bracket. Run a bead of Krazy glue around the gap between the rung and the plastic bracket. Again, you don't need to remove the rung from the bracket. You can let gravity pull the Krazy glue in.
Repeat until all the tape is off, and you're done!
comments.author: lauren_kelly

title: Ornament
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple ornament made from intersecting circles. It is parametric, so you can change around the diameter and height very easily. I've provided the OpenSCAD file for people to modify.
Update: Made the OpenSCAD file reflect the mathematics of this shape more correctly. You are making an equilateral triangle using intersecting circles. The angles of such a triangle are all 60 degrees, therefore, you must shift your circles by a factor of sin(60).
Print, and hang somewhere on your wall or use as a decoration on a tree.

author: Ferga2014

description.text:
This thing was revised on May 24, 2014. The revision added a 0.5mm thick surface to the clamping face of the part. The interior remains hollow. The older SolidWorks and .STL files have been deleted and replaced with the revised versions.  
The "Super Clamp" (manufactured by Manfrotto, et al.), is widely used by photographers and stage hands for mounting cameras, lights, audio and other equipment. A triangular insert is supplied with the Super Clamp. The insert is used when clamping to a flat support, such as a board, etc., however, these inserts are easily lost. Here's a replacement for the Super Clamp insert.   
Although this part doesn't look exactly like the original, it is perfectly functional. I printed in PLA, but ABS will work just fine.

• Print. (Prints nicely without support.)

description.text:
I need a machine for Milling small Things (alu, PCBÂ´s ) and wanted to be able to 3d Print as well so thats my solution
And I simply want to know what you people think about that ,..

Precaution : You need an 3 Axis mill and an 60Â° Mill for that but it should be great upgrade
The spindle is an standard "Kugelumlaufspindel" (if someone knows the propper therm for ballbearingspindle drop me an mail iÂ´ll then update it ;)-
which has an M14 nut this is driven by the Z Axis of the Mill.
The rest setup is standard RAMPS 1.4 and Stepper motors endstops , Steps:
1) Mill the baseplate (CUT2d will do the job Deskproto as well )
2) Mill The side Plate (Remark i will do an update to be able to mount the Printhead 180Â° turned to have the heavvy Stepper towards the inside !)
3) Drill the holes in the sidewalls in propper position
4) Drill the 6mm H7 holes
5.) Mount all for beeing able to mill the 60Â° Sideguards
Use your actual Z Guard to have an good fit.
(I had to do that 2 Times
To be done
6.) Mount all steppers & test it.
7.) Adjust marlin that it allows dangerous prints ;)-
Happy milling & Printing

description.text:
The Mercury Messenger Spacecraft mapped half of Mercury and sent the elevation data to The Planetary Data System. I got their files and made a 3D model. Data points are there every half degree of longitude and latitude. The elevations are exaggerated 5 times. The globe is 5.5 inches at sea level. Peaks are bigger.
TARGET_NAME = MERCURY
START_TIME = 2008-01-14
STOP_TIME = 2012-09-17
PRODUCT_CREATION_TIME = 2012-10-31
PRODUCT_RELEASE_DATE = 2013-03-08
PRODUCER_ID = MESSENGER_MLA_TEAM
PRODUCER_FULL_NAME = "DAVID E. SMITH"
PRODUCER_INSTITUTION_NAME = "NASA/GODDARD SPACE FLIGHT CENTER"

The Mercury data is available for you here:
http://pds-geosciences.wustl.edu/messenger/mess-e_v_h-mla-3_4-cdr_rdr-data-v1/messmla_2001/gdr/img/ That digital elevation data was used to make my Mercury Globe 3D model files in .stl format. I wrote a Perl program to make .stl files : like this program for Mercury:
$ivec = ($[4]-$[1])*($[8]-$[2])-($[5]-$[2])*($[7]-$_[1]);
$jvec = ($[5]-$[2])*($[6]-$[0])-($[3]-$[0])*($[8]-$_[2]);
$kvec = ($[3]-$[0])*($[7]-$[1])-($[4]-$[1])*($[6]-$_[0]);
$magnitude_squared = $i_vec$i_vec + $j_vec$j_vec + $k_vec*$k_vec;

comments.text: I would imagine such data wrangling takes a fast machine and quite a bit of patience . . . Thanks!

comments.text: No, the Mercury Globe 5x was made in an ordinary Acer Aspire One netbook. It is not a fast machine. Patience, yes, and focus on programming with no distractions from entertainment harpies.

title: Printrbot Maker 1405 CAD and STL files

description.text: This Thing is a model 1:1 model of the Printrbot Maker 1405 (2014) edition, one of the newest kits offered by Printrbot. When I started to look into designing my own mods I noticed that there was a lack of models for this particular version of the printrbot and was only able to find the DXF from Brooks on Youmagine. I used the DXF to create this model in solid works and convertd everything over to STL so that anyone can use it to design using it as a reference for dimensions, or to print up spares. The assemblies only include the Wood, Shafts and Bearings (some of the most important parts as far as getting the correct dimensions go.) meaning they do not include motors, hot end, belt, or threaded rod. Keep these things in mind when designing around the model.

author: Strider460

description.text: This house was designed as pice of the boardgame "Kingdom Builder" but might be used for several other boardgames too.

printed with:
Prusa Mendel
ABS
Nozzle: 0.5 mm @ 220 Â°C
carrier: glass (no coating) Skeinforge parameter advice:
It's best to use "Multiply" or arrange several of those small houses in one print run.
If only one house is printed it will either overheat or the printing time is increased massively when using the "Cool" option.
I tried 3 different parameter settings. The best results were achieved with a "Solid Surface Thickness" of 1 (just for reducing the amount of used material) and 1 "Extra Shell on Sparse Layers" but with "Infill Solidity" of 0.0. This causes the house to be empty inside but with 2 shells. The other 2 parameter settings used only 1 shell but with an "Infill Solidity" of either 0.25 or 0.0. Printing with only 1 shell resulted in lots of holes in the roof of the houses. However already an "Infill Solidity" of 0.0 seems sufficiently sturdy.

The OD of a 608 bearing is not a common Forstner drill size, so i created the plate to adapt a 1" hole in wood. There are tabs on the plate to lock it in place. This is only necessary if you slot the wood for adjusting.

print at leat 50% infill, plate side down the OD of the plate is slightly less then 1" to allow for slip fit.
The ID of the plate is a slip fit so to insert the bearing heat the PLA and press the bearing in on a flat surface. Drill the hole about .300" to give the bearing clearance.
Use this for compression loads (pressing into the wood), not tension loads
I'm using this for this project: http://www.solsylva.com/cnc/rotomolder.shtml

Rhinestones Ring. Diameter: 18mm.  
Update: The shank of first design was a little fragile. So the width was increased a little bit.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cYlyZUDHvbz
Made for my group of lunch friends.

Cooling fan for the Rigidbot.
A must for ABS printing to keep prints from warping.
Even PLA warps too, and a cooling fan will "set" the filament as it's extruded.
If you can't get the posts to fit or print well, you can cut them off and tape the fan on.
I may upload a bolt screw-in version in the near future if there are enough requests.

comments.text: I have printed this (or one very very similar to this) and it often gets in the way of my other prints and has pushed some things out of the way causing issues with the rest of the print.  Has anyone else had this problem and if so what was done to remedy the issue?
comments.author: runningwater

comments.text: There's lots of conflicting information on which fan plugs in where.  The rigidbot documentation says the extruder fan (included with rigidbot) should be in Fan2 (always on).  This makes sense because you don't want your PTFE tube or heatbreak to get hot.  So that means this cooling fan must go in Fan1 (PWM).  My default cura settings has M107 (cooling fan off).  Should I just change M107 to M106 S255 ?  Or would it be better to use "Tweak at Z" and turn on the fan at X% when I reach some Z height ?
comments.author: jkister

comments.text: Fan socket 1 should be for your heat sink fan. The default gcode start file starts the fan once it reaches around 4mm height. The second fan socket is always powered on.

author: maker3121

description.text:
I designed and built different FSR "mounts" in order to be able to use FSR for automatic bed leveling with my Rostock Mini.
I came up with three designs of which I'm right now using the last one (V3).
Even if version V2 has a small heightening I could not really get the bare FSR trigger correctly.
I ended up using version V3 together with those small rubber feet you get with a lot of electronic devices (see picture)
Version V3 has holes to mechanically mount it to the printer but those big paper clips also do a very good job here.
I maybe add something on top to keep the printing bed from going up on one side while the printing head is pushing it down on the other side but up to now this was not needed. Unfortunately, I could not get any firmware to work with complete auto bed leveling on my Rostock Mini but measuring the average z-height using G29 in Repetier firmware works like a charm with this construction.

comments.text:
Thanks for your comment. I tried different diameter but often had the problem that the triggering was done to often i.e. FSR was too sensitive. With my current set-up the weight of two pencils are triggering the FSR already.
Anyway, I will continue to investigate this.
comments.author: RostockMini4tw

comments.text: I'd recommend using rubber buttens that have a smaller base diameter. That will make the FSRs more sensitive to touch.

Need a peg? Broken your old one?
Need some that are easy to see in the dark?
Or just invested in a robot lawn mower and need endless amounts of pegs for installing the boundary cable? Customize your own peg to fit your need.

Print lying down for strength.
Obeys "rule of 45" so no support needed.
Pegs on pictures printed in PLA using 0.3 mm layer, 2 shells and 10% infill.
Small 5 grams pegs used in grass for robot lawn mower boundary cable printed in ~15 min.
Note: Due to poor programming some values will result in structures that are not manifold. If you have problems just try values close to the value you initially wanted.

title: Ultimate Samsung Galaxy Note 3 Case w/ Cover, Magnetized, Sugru

description.text:
UPDATE 10-15-2014
.
A uploaded a new version of the cover that gets rid of a small gap in the bottom corners, as brought to my attention by user Kareesmoon.
.
See this video for some of the features: http://youtu.be/rTBjehUN_zA
.
I was fed up with the dismal case options for my Samsung Note 3 phone, so I decided to build my own with all the features the other cases lacked, including a magnetized cover and Sugru bumpers.
.
Here are other variations:
  • No Bumpers (Magnets, Cover): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:414865
  • No Cover (Sugru Bumpers, No Magnets)
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:424089
  • No-Frills (No bumpers, no cover, no magnets): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:415418
    .
    I designed the case in three parts so that printers with small build areas (6"x6") such as the Printrbot Simple Metal could still print it.
    .
    The case features a protective cover with holes cut out to show the time and the music/audiobook/podcast navigation buttons. Now you can check the time in a theatre without distracting your fellow movie-goers!
    .
    The cover is held on by tiny magnets. You can purchase them for under 3 bucks here: http://amzn.to/1oqjeMp
    .
    I also added magnets to the back of the case so you can place the cover on the back when you're using the phone. The back magnets also allow you to use the cover as a stand. (See pictures.)
    .
    This case is designed to fit the Note 3 WITHOUT the original back piece. You can still access the battery by sliding off the two sections.
    .
    I initially printed a hole in the cover that allowed you to take pictures with the cover attached to the back, but I took this off because I realized I am always going to take the cover off when taking pictures.
    .
    The four corners have Sugru grips for added protection. I designed the corners so that the Sugru sticks securely. Buy Sugru at http://sugru.com or on Amazon here: http://amzn.to/1upL7Zw. Requires 2 small packs.
    .
    In the pictures above, I applied four coats of Plasti-Dip spray to the outer surfaces, but in retrospect, I don't recommend doing this. The Plasti-Dip eventually peeled off.
    .
    I went through 5 iterations before perfecting the case. After printing the version you see in the pictures, I added a half a millimeter extra to the length so you won't have a gap where the top and bottom meet. (Sand for a perfect fit.)

Parts list:
  • 1/8" x 1/16" magnets, quantity 18.. http://amzn.to/1oqjeMp
  • Sugru, 2 packs. http://amzn.to/1upL7Zw
  • Epoxy Adhesive, such as Loctite 5 Minute Instant Mix: http://amzn.to/1tqn1MR
    .
    1. Print the Top, Bottom, and Cover using support structures for the Top and Bottom. I highly recommend InTheGarage's Slic3r settings here: http://www.camwatt.com/printrbot-simple-metal-slic3r-settings.html
      .
    2. Clean out the support structures using pliers. Fine tune with a Dremel and sandpaper. Be very careful around the openings. Keep testing until you achieve a snug fit. (Remove Note 3 back before sliding on case. This case doesn't use the original back.) After printing the version in the pictures, I added a half millimeter extra of length to the edges where the Top and Bottom meet in order to get a gapless fit. You may need to sand these areas to achieve a perfect fit.
      .
    3. Lightly Dremel the magnet holes. There are 6 holes on the front of the case, 6 holes on the cover, and 6 holes on the back of the case. You want a tight fit. For some reason, even though the back case holes are sized the same as the other holes, they may print a little large. Just use a little extra glue for these in step 5.
      .
    4. You'll notice holes in the corners where the Sugru will eventually go. These are NOT for magnets. I added these so the Sugru will grip tightly and not come off. If you accidentally drill through the corners a little bit, don't worry. Sugru will eventually cover these areas.
      .
    5. Insert the magnets ( http://amzn.to/1oqjeMp ), securing with the adhesive of your choice. I recommend Epoxy Adhesive, such as Loctite 5 Minute Instant Mix available at Home Depot or here: http://amzn.to/1tqn1MR. I used a messier glue in the pictures, but the Epoxy should give you a much cleaner finish if you're careful. The polarity is EXTREMELY important. The front case magnets should all go in one direction. The back and cover case magnets need to go in the opposite direction of the front case magnets.
      .
    6. Open a pack of Sugru ( http://amzn.to/1upL7Zw ) and divide into 3 equal sections. Take one of these sections and sculpt around any corner except the one near the stylus. Repeat with two other corners (but not the stylus corner yet.)
      .
    7. Open another pack of Sugru and divide into 3 equal sections. Take a section and sculpt around the stylus corner. Take note of the microphone hole. Use a pin to poke out a hole in the Sugru so that the sound will come through. Make sure you are able to pull the Stylus in and out.
      .
    8. Take another section of Sugru and sculpt around the speaker hole. Sculpt an opening so the sound will come out.
      .
    9. Use the remaining Sugru to add where needed. I added a bit to the headphone jack area to get a nice seal.
      .
    10. Clean out excess Sugru. Slide the case over the phone to mold any inside Sugru to the phone's dimensions. Remove the phone and let the Sugru dry.
      .
    11. If the cover is warped, pour hot water over it and bend to fix the warp. If this doesn't work, put it inside the oven at 200 degrees for a minute, then remove and bend out the warp.
      .
    12. Remove the Note 3's original back piece and slide the case right over the exposed back. This case does not use the original back. You can easily access the battery and sd card by sliding off your new case's top and bottom.
      .
      Enjoy the case! Let me know if you have any suggestions for improvement.

This planetary gearbox was designed to provide a large reduction ratio in a relative small design. The bearing balls I used are 3.2 mm in diameter. After my harmonic drive prototype I wanted something smaller that could house a high reduction ratio into a smaller space. Also I wanted to get rid of the flexible parts.
The gearbox runs nice and smoothly. If you have any comments or if you need any custom parts for this thing (e.g. motor mount or shaft mount), please let me know! Thanks for viewing/watching! Animation:
http://youtu.be/m0P7M_uoYJ4
Video:
http://youtu.be/NRGnOpi60dw

The gearbox has the following buildup:
(All gears are module .75 gears)
1x 61 teeth gear (largest part, "bucket")
1x 62 teeth gear
4x combo gear (21 and 20 teeth)
1x small gear (20 teeth)
1x drive shaft (21 teeth)
When assembling please note that the 4 smaller gears are not exactly 90 degrees apart. two are 87.8 degrees apart, the others spaced 92.2 degrees.
I printed everything with a 93% flow rate. This was necessary as my first print (100%) was a bit too "thick" (the teeth were too big),

A simple, no-support printable spoolholder for miniFactory 3D printer.

This Spool holder consists of 2 parts, and is attachable (and removable, and re-attachable... :D) without any screws or tools. Just push the spool holder through the hole in miniFactory's upper right corner, and push the holder pin through the spool holder axis to lock it in place.
It holds most of the spools, smaller and bigger ones. It has very little friction so the spool runs smoothly on it. It's also located so, that the filament will run from it into feeder without any extra parts, even when making higher prints. UPDATE:
There's now a shorter version of the Spool Holder, that works better with spools that have thinner edge. Also, The lock-part has been enhanced so, that you can use the spool holder on either side of miniFactory 3D printer - or Both, if that's what you want :)

A simple half-case for a standard bipolar stepper motor. The top is attached to the bottom with M2 bolts, the case is screwed into the motor with M4 bolts. The case itself doesn't attach to anything, it was meant to have brackets holding four magnets at the bottom to be attached to a whiteboard, but whiteboards generally aren't attractive enough to magnets. So, to make this useful, you'll have to design your own bracket at the bottom, to be attached with a M2 bolts. See it in "action" here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F-EYcO8IZ2I

description.text:
Mount for the Boscam TR1 camera / FPV transmitter.  Base designed to accept a standard-sized Mobius ActionCam piece of velcro, so you can (usually) fit the Boscam where you used to put your Mobius.  
The Boscam gets quite warm when working, so the mount provides clearance to allow a cooling airflow.  
OpenScad source file uploaded as well as the STL file in case anyone wants to tweak the design to suit their application.

description.text:
I tried many times to print thing:19304 (in PLA) however the outcomes were disappointing.  The nipples & divots for the axes were too small, so the concentric didn't stay together.  I changed the whosawhatsis' original OpenSCAD script to increase the size of both nipples & divots.  If anything, they are a bit too big however this is nothing an xacto knife couldn't take care of...
The SCAD file is close, but not the exact one used to produce the STL. I once again forgot to save my updated file in OpenSCAD.
Print, then turn every other stage 90 degrees and snap them into place.

title: Heart shape mermaid jewel box remix

description.text:
Here is a remix of the heart shaped jewel box mixed with a mermaid. I made this for my little sister and although it was a quick print I think it
came out quite well.

There are two different top designs to choose from, one is my remixed
mermaid top and the other is the original top with a separate mermaid
to ease in printing. I have made both and ended up printing the top
separately only so I could print face down directly on the glass and get a glossy top finish. I then just epoxy glued the mermaid on top after
I had given it a quick spray with gloss silver paint.

comments.text:
For the supports, I have a Davinci 1.0 printer and I used the xyzware supports as they are really good and easy to remove.
They are basically rectalinear supports at 45 degree angle and about 2mm spacing, thats the basic slic3r settings you would use.

description.text: Blind plug to give you plain earth / ground connection - could be used for ESD mats, ESD bracelets, etc... In this case it was used to properly ground a cheap radio scanner's casing.

The brass inlet was taken from a chead plug, the print was done using the Mendel I3 Berlin, 1.75mm PLA, 0.4mm layer and wall thickness, 12.5% squared infill - works a treat...
But only in certain european countries, where they have real secure and rock solid electrical connections - sorry, Americans... You can't have it all! :-)

I already wrote this up and then I lost it, so here's the short descriptor for now:  I broke my temples, put lame metal skinny ones on, and decided that was enough.  These are printed in two pieces, joined and melt-welded together, and work pretty darned well.  For the opposite side you just print the file mirrored, and VOILA, working eyeglasses! Casing for self buildt dipol antenna - forms the center part of the antenna to mount a BNC jack and the dipol radials. There are two versions available, one with and one without wall mount.

Casing printed in PLA with 100% squared infill to give it enough stability to hold the radial tubings.
Dipol itself is made out of heavy copper ground wire. The radial tubings are made out of plain 16mm PVC wire tubing usually used for house installation. The end caps are 16mm chair leg protectors.
Everything is glued together with a special glue (Germans: Pattex PLASTIX), that also works fine on PLA. Copper wire and BNC jack installation is additionally hold in place with hot glue - be careful when using PLA: Hot glue tends to be a little bit too warm for PLA! Using too much at a time will damage (melt) the casing!

description.text:
Experimenting with a support beam and a sliding insert, rendered these results. Could be adapted for many uses. Don't expect precision alignment as it is a loose fit, but will allow for use as a tracked slider. Good exercise for seeing how well your printer can print.
Mine produced prints that fit nicely without need for tweaking
. Added a lockable slide version with mounting holes. All holes are for 6-32 tap.
When tapping plastics, Use 91% Isopropyl alcohol as a tapping lubricant and break chips more frequently than you would for metal. You'll get very good threads despite how odd it may sound. Added Slider 90 beam which is slotted to allow it to be glued to a slider at a 90 degree angle. 09/13/14

Beam is 60mm long (glue multiple pieces together for longer track needs)
Slider is 30mm long can be attached to something you want to have limited or guided movement.
Print the beams in their vertical position (as shown) for best results.
Set infill to 35% (recommended) or higher
no raft or supports
Hope someone finds this "Thing" useful.

title: Tensioner for X Axis - Printrbot Simple

description.text: This is is a two piece tensioner for the Printrbot Simple that uses a string for the drive belt.   It's a compact design and prints quickly.   See instruction tab for more info.

Print the pieces
Remove top bed. (The lower bed can stay assembled)
Align the spring holder as shown in the picture
Drill a hole and fasten the holder (3mm x 12mm screw for all)
Attach extension spring (see pic for hardware from Home Depot)
Align the corner piece and fasten
Wrap the string around the motor and tie the string to spring. To get the proper tension, tie the string before placing it over the corner piece. Pull the string over the corner piece and you will have good tension.

The Assembly file is primarily for display, but it is also shows how the kit parts are assembled.
The parts are modeled in 1/2-inch = 1-ft scale. The numbers in the file names are the number of parts of that type to be incorporated in the assembly.
I got the basic model, “wagon bogie” by Ivan Liu as an Autodesk 123D Design file from the Autodesk gallery. I used 123D Design and Meshmixer to modify the parts for 3D printing. All parts except the axels are flat on one side for printing without supports. The brake mechanism in the center is simplified as a silhouette of the multiple moving parts of the original model. I used the wheels from Makerbot's Big Boy http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:259005, because they had better resolution than the ones from Liu's model.

title: "Red Duck" First Take Off of a fully printed flying wing.

description.text:
My intention was to design a plane up to 3 m wingspan without strengthening by carbon tubes - that means 100% printed.
But I had to stop at 1,35 m because the wing reached already a weight of almost 1,1 kg. My small motor which I used already on my sail plane http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:86982 wouldn't last for much more weight.
Additionelly I thought a flying wing would make less problems to get the CG forwards, because of the short tail. But again I got the same trouble. The big mass of the wing pushed the CG backwards, so I was forced to add a spacer on front. This makes the plane looks a bit like a duck ;-)
Nevertheless I fasten the wing ends just with tape to have the ability to extend the wing span at any time.
Uli Richter - a long standing pilot of the Lufthansa and very experienced in building and flying air plane models - was so kind to fly my wing plane. He had absolutely no problems and showed us immediately a fully acrobatic flight show. Thank you very much for the wonderfull flights!
It was not so easy to follow with the camera all the unexpected maneuver in flight. Therefore the video can't give by far the impression as it was in reality. http://youtu.be/c6Udkt3NSK0
My Club: http://hackerspace-ffm.de/

Specifications
wing span: 1350 mm
wing chord: 336 mm
aerodynamic center: 78.1 mm
aerodynamic center 5% stability: 61.3 mm
wing profil: Clark YS
wing overall weight: 1100 g
wing area: 45,36 dm²
fuselage overall weight 680 g
wing loading: 39,2 g/dm²
directional stability (Thies) STFs: 38
motor: Robbe Roxxy BL Outrunner 2834-08
propeller: Aeronaut CAM 10 x 6”
static thrust: 1100 g (3S Lipo)
Print and Material
print time wing: 81 h
print time fuselage: 35 h
used PLA: 1.4 kg
.
Update 2014/09/29
"fuselage 02 brim.stl" replaced by "fuselage 02 mod brim.stl"
The lower edge of the border is rounded for easier printing.
.
The next days I will give more information.

title: Weber Style BBQ Wireless Thermometer Receiver Stand

description.text:
This is a stand to hold the receiver of the "Weber Style" wireless BBQ thermometer.
I was tired of not being able to read the BBQ temperature on the receiver because it was laying on the table.  There was a stand with this receiver, but it was flimsy and broke, then got lost.
These "Weber Style" BBQ thermometers are available all over the place, and the are really great because you can monitor the temperature of the meat from in the comfort of your kitchen.
Print it out and enjoy.  The receiver fits into the base so the thicker end of the base is in the back.

author: TechShopJim

description.text:
This free public domain deer skull was scanned and digitally cleaned up by myself. Scan done via Agisoft PhotoScan.  
"Spike the Deer Skull" has been modified by myself from the original scan data to smooth over some distortions and close up gaps, etc, generally getting the mesh ready for print or use in other applications. Euphoria Deer Skull Raw Data.zip contains a fully textured high resolution obj and jpeg texture, without any smoothing decimation, or optimisation.  
Spike may receive future updates to improve printability, as they haven't been printed yet.  
Being a part of nature, it is of course a part of the public domain. I hope to see some cool remixes of this authentic precise reproduction! The details on this scan are truly incredible!

comments.text: This scan is great! So much detail. I was thinking of using this for some antler mounts. Would it be possible to stretch/move the antler bases? White tail deer have a wider skull shape than this species you have scanned.

author: bre

description.text:
HEY!!!
Don't bother printing this, it wobbles too much! Print Lite Arm i2 instead it is more stable and requires less specialized components:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:480446
-Armatec Update 08/14/2014
I will be uploading all add-on parts here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:428391
Update 8/13/14____
If you want to make and sell these please send me a link to your ebay listing (or whatever) so I can point people in that direction I am not sure I can keep up with demand with only one printer, and I want people to have access to parts when they need them.
(SOLD OUT) http://m.ebay.com/itm?itemId=181492881972#

This is a fully 3D printable robotic arm modeled after the U Factory uArm,
http://store.ufactory.cc/complete-assembled-acrylic-kit/
which is modeled after the ABB Robotics IRB-660
http://www.robots.com/abb/irb-660
and the Aliexpress MG995 Hobby Robot Kit.
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/MG995-robotic-mechanic-arm-4-axis-stacker-servos-arduino-Control-Palletizing-Model-four-axis-with/1853249583.html
This arm is fully compatible with the uArm software as long as you use their Arduino Shield. All of these parts were designed by me in Google Sketchup, which I have included both a copy of the software for Google Sketchup 8, along with the STL exporting plugin and the files that were used to produce the CAD images and parts list. You can use sketchup and modify any of the parts as you see fit, this Is my gift to the community, enjoy!
The goal is to make the "Lite Arm" a common open source robotic arm, and to proliferate it as widely as possible.
There are a lot of people working with robotic arms, and doing many interesting things. I think it would be great if we were able to directly benefit from the work others are doing, and share the software that enables a variety of tasks, first we need a common format for that sort of thing to work well.
I would love to see this hardware capable of self replication. Perhaps we can attach an extruder and have it 3D print it’s own parts and upgrades, as well as retaining the capacity to assemble itself at some point with future iterations.
This will require some hard work in developing the software.
Many hands make "Lite" work.
This project is carried over from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:320004
My last project
Lance Pierson
www.armatecgroup.org
[email protected]

Take a look at the uarm instructions, they are very similar, I will add a more detailed instruction later. for a parts list also look at the uarm instructions, I have provided an additional pdf from my ebay shopping cart.

author: antlvk

description.text:
Here are photos of a test tube ant-farm I use instead of concrete or plaster artificial nest.
It is used since last year, so it is viable.
It is an evolution of the v1 : I've used threaded rods instead of a wood frame, and test tubes enter a hole instead of surrounding a washer.
the aim is to get a low maintenance ant-farm, test tubes providing moisture for months. test tubes can be removed provinding access to brood if needed. Designed for 20ml test tubes (16,3mm x 150mm).
I'm still thinking about a look-a-like thing, I think a V3 will be a mashup of V1 and V2.
And maybe V4 will be a pintable setting.

Update : use 160116-v3-plexi for the PMMA. the way out for the 5/8mm pvc clear tube was not enough wide in the previous file. Use 4mm threaded rods, nuts and bolts.
3mm thick Plexiglass PMMA.
Plexiglass or wood for other parts.
5/8 mm PVC clear tube.
Should be obvious with photos, but don't hesitate to ask, so I'll have an oppurtunity to improve instructions ;)

author: Protorap

description.text: Self-explanatory

This Thing is a extension for a microSD card. It is meant to make it easier to get the card into and out of a tight space, like the printrboard of a Printrbot 1405 (the one I designed it for). I got the idea from the L shaped sd holder for Printrbots I saw out there already, but I needed it to be straight for my printer.
V1 is just a handle that can only be removed from the SD card by sliding the card in and out from the side. For the Printrbot Maker 1405 that means during operation the handle can not be removed. (you could slice off the end stop and print just 1/2 of the holder so it could slide off or...) I have broken two sd cards by accidentally leaving the card plugged in with V1 and messing about with my printer. If you go with V1 just be careful not to do anything but pull it in and out.

comments.author: Dr_Joel

comments.text: I watched the video and seeing where the card slot on your printer is the slide in approach of your holder was a fantastic idea that I used for the first handle I printed. I would have used your design but on the 1405 the slot is inset way too far and a straight in approach was all I could see working. I uploaded the tweezers I modeled this morning and I am really happy with them, but you're right, I cant see a way to make tweezers for your situation.

maybe if it's for a "straight-in" application, it will work better.
